29.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain, full of meaty
goodness. Coming up Andy is killing two birds,

36.text:
sorry rats, with one stone, sorry stick. He
is clearing his barn of straw and rodents

43.text:
Whose dog is that? I hear you ask. Well if
you want to avoid the answer, yours sir, watch

49.text:
our top gun training tips from Skinners Petfood.
We have got News Stump, Hunting YouTube and

57.text: an extraordinary Hallo Charlie from Scotland.

60.text:
First, Subaru is about to launch its new Forester,
but is the original cross over still fit for

68.text:
farmyards and off road forays. Well, Sporting
Shooter editor and ace motoring journalist,

74.text:
Dom Holtam goes deer stalking in the Lake
District to find out.

79.text:
When Dom was given the chance to test drive
the new Subaru Forester up north we all thought

85.text:
it would a good excuse to take it on a proper
Fieldsports Britain outing. So instead of

90.text:
going for a pleasant drive in the country
with lines like ‘If this car were a sheep

95.text:
it would be producing knitted woolly jumpers',
we're taking it off the beaten track, on to

101.text:
a beaten up farm, to reach the start of a
hill stalking day in the Lake District. We're

106.text:
after a cull red stag with our old friend,
Cumbrian deerstalker Jonathan Standing.

113.text:
First Dom needs to get his rifle zeroed. Shooting
up here is not recommended for the novice.

118.text:
The strong cross winds are a big problem and,
although Dom has stalked with Jonathan for

123.text:
years, both of them need to know the rifle
is shooting true.

125.text:
As always when the rifle has been in the back
of the car, we just got here, just want to

130.text:
make sure the rifle is still on zero. So Jonathan
has brought us out to check that we can still

136.text:
hit the paper then makes us that bit more
confident when we do go out on the hill that

139.text:
hopefully the rifle is still doing its thing
and any mistakes are down to me and not down

144.text:
to a problem with the gun. So I am just going
to have three shots and hopefully make sure

150.text:
We'll leave them to it and back to the Forester.
At its launch back in 1997 you may recall

156.text:
it found favour with farmers and farmers'
wives, husbands and live-in lovers alike.

161.text:
These days everyone needs a car like this
just to survive the pot holes. But has this

166.text:
tough old boot, now with it's fourth generation,
gone soft.

170.text:
In many ways the original Subaru Forrester
came to define what we now call the cross

174.text:
over genre. Cross over - it is not quite a
car, it is not quite a proper off roader,

179.text:
it is something between the two. It is a pumped
up estate car and in the case of the Forrester

184.text:
it was tough, it was reliable. It had a proper
four wheel drive system. It was built to take

189.text:
punishment and it found favour with farmers
and families all over the world. Case in point,

195.text:
this is David the cameraman's car. It has
led a very tough life chasing Fieldsport Britain

200.text:
stories all over the UK. He has got kids,
it has been dealt with as a farm vehicle and

206.text:
it survived. And it is still going strong,
135,000 miles, still great. And the market

212.text:
has changed, it has moved on. Cross over vehicles
are not a rarity any more they are everywhere

217.text:
from urban vehicles all the way through to
slightly more serious stuff. So the new Subaru

221.text:
Forrester has got a much tougher segment in
which to compete and this is it. As you can

227.text: see just looking at the two together

229.text:
it is much taller, it is much chunkier, it
has got much more road presence. It has got

234.text:
the new Subaru corporate face if you like
with the big badge, big lights, plenty of

239.text:
ride height. It also demanding to have a lot
more luxury in this sector. So whereas before

245.text:
you could get away with a vehicle that was
quite utilitarian, these days it needs to

248.text:
have sat nav, it needs to have electrics,
it needs to have controls on the steering

252.text:
wheel, it needs to have iPod connectivity.
Another big change for this generation of

257.text:
Forrester is that it has now got the next
generation of the Boxer diesel engine. The

261.text:
original Forrester, petrol only. Yes, you
could have a turbo which is great fun, but

265.text:
you couldn't have a diesel. This does it's
a flat fourth configuration, that Subaru made

270.text:
famous, much more efficient, much smoother
and means it is more practical as a family

277.text:
The country up here is just beautiful. Better
viewed on foot than in a vehicle. The last

282.text:
time we were here was with American huntress
Pam Zaitz.

286.text:
Dom and Jonathan scan the hillside and the
dots in the distance do appear to be deer.

291.text:
They aren't going to come to us, so we've
got to go to them!

294.text:
I think Jonathan has taken one look at that
hill and one look at my beer belly and he

298.text:
didn't fancy my chances very much. We are
going to head out on to the open hill and

300.text:
just have a scan round to see what we can
see. But sadly, even with the Forrester's

303.text:
ability it is not going to make it up there.
So we are going to need something a little

311.text:
The conditions are blowy to say the least.
The stalking team stop and scan as they ascend

316.text: - there's no point heading off blindly.

318.text:
It is moving across the face, it is moving
across the face.

323.text:
Yesterday it was T shirt weather back down
south. We seem to have travelled back about

328.text:
four months. It feels like December, January
up here again. There is still a bit of snow

334.text:
on the ground, but my main concern is this
wind. It is absolutely howling over the tops

336.text:
and where it is going up and down the valleys
it is hard to predict exactly which direction

342.text:
the wind is blowing where the deer are. We
have picked up another group that are directly

347.text:
opposite us and are kind of moving along the
face trying to keep in a bit of shelter, so

354.text:
we are just going to monitor and see where
they end up.

355.text:
They need to spot a target and work towards
it as stealthily as they can.

360.text:
Eventually Jonathan finds some likely customers.
A slight movement catches his eye and more

365.text: careful study reveals a herd of eight animals.

369.text:
This is when the fun begins and where careful
preparation for this environment is vital

372.text: - not just fitness but kit too.

376.text:
They crawl, they walk - they try and get a
breath - they crawl some more and more. Once

382.text:
you're wet you're wet and you just get on
with it.

385.text:
Jonathan is fantastic at reading the deer
- knowing when to move his clients - when

393.text:
I'm getting more like a sausage roll David.
Normally when I am that low to the ground

419.text:
I am asleep. The thing is if you spook them
now I am going to cry.

420.text:
After 45 minutes the first chance of a shot
is at a young red stag calf. But they bounce

426.text:
Jonathan is now keener than ever to get on
to these animals as one of the hinds looks

430.text:
sick - even though the hind season is over,
many have perished with the severe winter

437.text: This time Dom is in position and happy.

446.text: That is the exit isn't it. Heart shot ...

465.text:
The 235-metre shot strikes the hind well and
a heart shot puts her down.

474.text:
On closer inspection Jonathan knows he's made
the right call.

478.text:
We picked this hind out because it was the
poorest one in the herd and now we have shot

482.text:
it we can see why. There is no flesh on its
back at all. Back bone is showing right along.

487.text:
So it is a good one to take it is. Might have
even died in the next couple of weeks like

495.text: this. It just made it through the winter.

496.text:
Where we have had this prolonged spell of
cold through into March it has put extra pressure

501.text:
on them, because this is the time of year
when they are vulnerable isn't it?

504.text:
Often they don't die in the winter, but die
when the spring comes they do. Yes. This is

508.text: when you get the losses this time of year.

511.text:
All that needs to be done now is get her back
to the Polaris, which is a very long way away.

519.text:
However that's not the end of Dom's day - a
single red hind with an injured leg gets up

524.text:
on the walk back to the cars. Jonathan asks
Dom to get on to her.

531.text: Wasn't moving very well at all was it.

542.text:
She's down and on closer inspection she has
a broken leg but, incredibly, is a far healthier

551.text:
It was on its own. It got up out of these
reeds and it just didn't want to go anywhere

557.text:
Normally they see you, as we know from earlier,
soon as they catch any sight of you they want

562.text:
to be away. Whereas this one just didn't and
stood there looking and looking. And Jonathan

569.text:
soon as he saw it moving could see something
wasn't right and it has got a bad break to

573.text:
the front leg. Didn't want to go up the hill,
didn't want to get away. Stood there looking

578.text:
and looking and unfortunately that gave us
time to get the rifle out and get a shot in

582.text:
it. Even having said that look at the size
of the beast and the condition of it compared

587.text:
to the other one we shot earlier. This one
is in much better physical nick. Obviously

592.text:
it is worrying when you see one like that
on its own not wanting to move.

598.text:
What a stalk. Not what we'd hoped but stalking
up here is a different beast for all sorts

604.text:
As always welfare of the animal comes first.
Paramount it is, yes, yes, you may be after

610.text:
one thing but something else dictates to you
a different plan for the day which we did

616.text:
I will just have to wait another time to get
my stag.

619.text:
Yes you will I am afraid. The day didn't go
as we planned, but it turned out a good day

626.text:
in the end really. We have stopped any animal
suffering on the hill which is good.

634.text:
All everyone needs to do now is dry off and
get some shots of the Subaru before it gets

638.text:
too late. We've been on the hill far longer
than expected.

647.text:
Yes the new Subaru Forester has to compete
with the likes of the Qashqais, the Kugas

650.text:
and and the Tiguans of this world. Yes, they
also have good ground clearance and some even

654.text:
have four-wheel drive, but it's like comparing
hill stalking for reds with woodland stalking

659.text:
for muntjac. The new softroaders potter whereas
the Forester still has the core strength to

667.text:
Dom looking comfortable behind the wheel and
the rifle there. And if you want to see more

of Dom's reviews of vehicles from super cars
to SUV's to UTV's click on the screen which

678.text:
has appeared in the tree behind me there.
Now for our very own rough rider it's David

683.text: on the Fieldsports Channel News Stump.

694.text:
Another hunting case has collapsed. The prosecution
against the joint-master and huntsman of the

699.text:
Weston and Banwell Harriers, George Milton,
was thrown out by magistrates in Taunton who

705.text:
said Mr Milton has no case to answer. The
League Against Cruel Sports has spent more

710.text:
than £2 million of charitable donations on
'investigations' since 2010, yet has achieved

717.text:
no successful Hunting Act prosecutions as
a result of its activities in the past two

724.text:
While some American states are cracking down

729.text:

734.text:

738.text:

747.text:
Meanwhile in Malta, bird rights activists
from BirdLife International are watching the

752.text:
island's 9,500 hunters to make sure they stick
to quail and turtle doves. In this video,

759.text:
by Malta Today, the journalist listens unquestioning
as a BirdLIfe member reels of a list of others

765.text:
birds he claims hunters have shot at. The
antis are angry because the Maltese government

769.text:
has ruled that shooters do not have to wear
identifying fluorescent armbands.

775.text:
Here's a more heart warming story, which you
can help with. Gamekeeper's daughter Lily

779.text:
Bignell wants a new set of wheels. Glanusk
Estate head keeper Steve Bignell is raising

784.text:
funds to purchase an off-road wheelchair for
his 8 year old daughter Lily. He's holding

788.text:
a charity clay shoot on the 9th June at the
Estate. Look for Lily's New Wheels on Facebook.

794.text: More on the KeepersMate blog, KeepersMate.co.uk/blog

800.text:
And finally, a Hawaiin fisherman had a close
encounter with a nine-foot shark which jumped

804.text:
out of the water close to his kayak. Isaac
Brumaghim, 37, was fishing off the coast of

809.text:
Hawaii when the shark sprang up and bit the
tuna he was trying to catch. As well as being

814.text:
shocked and scared by the experience, he said
he was extremely annoyed that the shark had

820.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain

attacking rats. First we have game birds attacking

Hallo Charlie, it is Andy here from north

885.text:
Send us your own Hallo Charlie - film yourself

hallo Charlie, who you are and what you're
up to. Then share it or email it via YouTube,

Facebook, DropBox or YouSendIt, you name it

901.text:
There is a certain person who has been obvious
by his absence in the last few weeks. He has

907.text:
been off to warmer climes parading his budgie
smugglers around the pool and working off

912.text:
his tight buns. Who writes this stuff on the
farm. Well he is back this week. Not with

917.text:
pigeons, but with fast action terrier work
on rats. It is Andy the Crowman Crow.

925.text:
Andy has had a few problems with rats this
year..

928.text:
When the guys laying concrete in his new barn
broke the door it was an open invitation for

933.text:
the local Rattus norvegicus population to
over-winter in straw destined for the burner.

940.text:
Air rifles have taken care of a few of them,
Andy's fancy footwork others, today the question

946.text:
is going to be who let the dogs out? Who,
who, who, who? First of all where's he been?

954.text:
Where was I last month? Um I was here I suspect
fertilising or something .

957.text:
Gambia, oh that is right. Yes I was fishing
in Gambia. I had to pay for that, you get

962.text:
yours paid for including flights. Anyway end
of... that is where I have been. I have been

966.text:
flat out doing field work. I am all up together
now so the plan is we are going to extend

974.text:
the wall over there with some more grain walling
so they have got further to run. We are going

979.text:
to blanket off at the back either side and
I have got a bit of moving about to do so

985.text:
if I get that done you can speak to John.
He is a mate of mine he has brought his terriers

989.text:
Inside the barn Andy is creating what looks
like a five-a-side football pitch. If things

994.text:
go right we can expect a few rats to come
charging down the wing.

999.text:
John owns the dogs. They are all shapes and
sizes. So, what makes a good ratter.?

1003.text:
Boldness. One that doesn't make off. These
have been at it ... this one is 12 now. She

1004.text:
has been at it for a long, long time. They
are just keen. Stay ...

1010.text: What do you think about rats?

1012.text:
I quite like them to be quite honest. I have
got great respect for them. They are world

1021.text:
survivors. You can have them in a cold store
where they grow a longer fur coat. You can

1025.text:
have them as with Andy's in the grain store,
plenty of food and they will then breed to

1033.text:
the food source. If there is a shortage of
food source they won't breed. Sorry, they

1039.text:
John is no stranger to cameras. A few years
ago he appeared on a BBC documentory with

1045.text:
Martin Clunes looking at different dogs breeds
and their roles - the film also featured a

1050.text:
young Crow. So how was Doc Martin with the
ratting?

1054.text:
After the initial shock he warmed to the task
shall I say.

1060.text:
With the arena coming together word is spreading
and we have a reasonable team building. Andy

1065.text:
Jnr is up aloft directing traffic, three with

1072.text:
- Gladiators ready let's start moving those

1076.text:
With half the bales gone, things start livening

and we get some screamers. Richard intercepts

1100.text: the dogs run out of space -

Andy even leaves the cab for a bit of goal

1107.text:
and the dogs and sticks do the rest. Let's

1114.text:
It really does start to get frantic - sticks
waving - dogs running and chewing and eating

1118.text:
...argghhh - no accounting for taste - it's

1124.text:
Even the youngster gets his first rat - it
really is built into the DNA with these dogs.

1131.text:
I was expecting a lot more than that. There
is a small hole that goes into the walling

1140.text:
up the side there, centre partition up the
middle there. There is a small hole in that

1146.text:
so we have lost quite a few in there which
is a bit of a pain, but hopefully you got

a bit of footage. Like I say I was hoping
for a few more, but every dead rat is a good

1158.text:
Yes, it is exciting stuff. There are several
nests of youngsters we got as well. Got seven

1163.text:
or eight in some of those. I think there about
five or six lots. Dom I love you ...

1167.text: on the farm. It is amazing.

I have never seen Andy drive a loader that
fast either. It normally takes him about two

1188.text:
Even though Andy says he is a bit disappointed
it's been great fun...

1192.text:
Yes, it was brilliant. Proper good. Good dogs

1198.text:
Think they did very well. I am very pleased
with them. First time. Missed a couple myself,

1202.text: but he got them so that is ok.

When you see that first rat run out. That

want to do is chase after it and get there

1214.text:
They think it's all over, except John who

1220.text:
It doesn't matter how many times you do it

Ratting - a great method of vermin control

1234.text:
Now from terriers to, dare I say it better
bred dogs, all you gun dog owners out there

1251.text:
Many people say you should always take a tennis
ball and a racquet when you go for a walk

1254.text:
with your gundog. It is, they insist, a perfect
training opportunity. Top gundog trainer Howard

1261.text:
Kirby has lots more to say on the subject
of tennis balls.

1264.text:
We need our spaniels, all of our dogs really
to enter cover in order to find game with

1269.text:
a retriever to go and find it and with a spaniel
to go and flush and get in there. So we make

1274.text:
the game enjoyable. We roll a tennis ball
into soft cover not too harsh cover at this

1279.text:
stage otherwise there is a danger you will
frighten him. Too many prickles in his face

1282.text:
he might not want to go in there again. So
it is a gradual build up again. What we did

1286.text:
was we put a ball into the cover, we just
encouraged the dog to hunt, I did what we

1290.text:
call clicked him off. I made a noise that
indicated that I wanted him to start hunting,

1293.text:
so where is it then ... so he starts to hunt
and gradually over a period of months he gets

1298.text:
familiar with that command and he thinks oh
there must be something for me to find, he

1301.text:
starts to hunt and blow me he finds a tennis
ball. What happens is he thinks my dad is

1305.text:
really great because every time he tells me
to hunt I find a tennis ball. So if he tells

1308.text:
me to hunt, then I am going to do it every
time. That is

1310.text:
the secret. And we build that up so that the
dog hunts for longer with less aids from you.

1315.text:
He gets more powerful. He holds an area and
enters cover and pick it up. What we also

1320.text:
do there is as soon as he has picked it up
he has to come out and deliver it to hand.

1324.text:
So he comes out and retrieves, delivers the
bird or ball to hand. We then develop that

1329.text:
exercise up because more often than not a
spaniel will be used for flushing and not

1334.text:
for retrieving out of cover so much. So he
goes in to cover where there is no ball. Bearing

1339.text:
in mind we have conditioned him that when
you say start hunting he starts hunting. So

1343.text:
while he is hunting I flick a ball in the
air, we fire a pretend shot, bang or fire

1348.text:
a starting pistol and we are starting to simulate
the whole process, the process he will go

1350.text:
through on live game in the future. So we
are teaching him to sit to the flush, look

1357.text:
and when we say get out, he will go out and
retrieve.
